title: Introduction to HTML
summary: Learn the basics of HTML structure and tags.
description: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the foundation of web development. This lesson covers the basic structure of an HTML document and common HTML elements.
learningObjectives: Understand what HTML is and its purpose

slides.title: What is HTML?
slides.content:
What is HTML?

HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the foundation of web development. It's the standard markup language for creating web pages.

HTML describes the structure of a web page using markup elements called tags.

slides.title: HTML Structure
slides.content:
Basic HTML Structure

Every HTML document has a basic structure:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Page Title</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <h1>Hello World!</h1>
  </body>
</html>

slides.title: Common HTML Tags
slides.content:
Common HTML Tags

  • <h1> to <h6> - Headings
  • <p> - Paragraphs
  • <a> - Links
  • <img> - Images
  • <div> - Containers

title: HTML Forms and Input
summary: Create interactive forms to collect user input.
description: Learn how to create forms in HTML, including various input types, labels, and form validation. Forms are essential for user interaction on websites.
learningObjectives: Create HTML forms with various input types

slides.title: HTML Forms
slides.content:
HTML Forms

Forms allow users to input data on web pages. They're essential for login pages, contact forms, surveys, and more.

<form action='/submit' method='post'>
  <input type='text' name='username'>
  <button type='submit'>Submit</button>
</form>

slides.title: Input Types
slides.content:
Common Input Types

  • text - Single-line text
  • email - Email address
  • password - Hidden password
  • number - Numeric input
  • checkbox - Multiple selections
  • radio - Single selection

title: Semantic HTML Elements
summary: Use semantic HTML for better structure and accessibility.
description: Semantic HTML elements clearly describe their meaning to both the browser and developer. Learn about header, nav, main, article, section, aside, and footer elements.
learningObjectives: Understand the importance of semantic HTML
Use semantic elements for page structure

slides.title: Why Semantic HTML Matters
slides.content:
Why Semantic HTML Matters

Semantic HTML uses elements that clearly describe their meaning and purpose. This improves accessibility, SEO, and code maintainability.

Instead of using generic

elements everywhere, semantic elements like
,
, and
provide context about the content they contain.

slides.title: Structural Elements
slides.content:
Structural Elements

  • - Contains introductory content or navigation
  • - Navigation links
  • - Main content of the page
  • - Thematic grouping of content
  • - Self-contained content
  • - Sidebar or supplementary content
  • - Footer information

slides.title: Semantic Page Structure
slides.content:
Semantic Page Structure

A well-structured semantic HTML page follows this pattern:


  
...





  
...

  
...




...

This structure helps screen readers navigate and search engines understand your content.

slides.title: Accessibility Benefits
slides.content:
Accessibility Benefits

Semantic HTML improves accessibility by:

  • Providing landmarks for screen readers
  • Creating logical content hierarchy
  • Enabling keyboard navigation
  • Supporting assistive technologies

Screen readers can jump between sections using semantic landmarks, making content much easier to navigate.

title: CSS Fundamentals
summary: Learn how to style your HTML with CSS.
description: Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) is used to style and layout web pages. This lesson covers the basics of CSS selectors, properties, and values.
learningObjectives: Learn how to apply styles to HTML elements
Work with colors, fonts, and spacing

slides.title: What is CSS?
slides.content:
What is CSS?

CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is a language used to describe the presentation of a document written in HTML. It controls how HTML elements look on screen, paper, or in other media.

CSS separates content from presentation, making websites more maintainable and flexible.

slides.title: CSS Syntax
slides.content:
CSS Syntax

CSS rules consist of a selector and declaration block:

selector {
  property: value;
  property: value;
}

The selector targets HTML elements, and the declarations specify what styles to apply.

slides.title: Common Selectors
slides.content:
Common Selectors

  • Element selector: p { color: blue; }
  • Class selector: .highlight { background: yellow; }
  • ID selector: #header { font-size: 24px; }
  • Universal selector: * { margin: 0; }

slides.title: Colors and Fonts
slides.content:
Colors and Fonts

CSS provides many ways to specify colors:

  • Named colors: red, blue, green
  • Hex codes: #ff0000, #3366cc
  • RGB values: rgb(255, 0, 0)

Font properties include font-family, font-size, and font-weight.

slides.title: The Box Model
slides.content:
The Box Model

Every HTML element is a rectangular box with content, padding, border, and margin:

  • Content: The actual content (text, images, etc.)
  • Padding: Space between content and border
  • Border: Line around the padding
  • Margin: Space outside the border

Understanding the box model is crucial for layout and spacing.

title: CSS Flexbox Layout
summary: Master flexible box layouts with Flexbox.
description: Flexbox is a powerful layout system that makes it easy to design flexible responsive layout structures. Learn how to align and distribute space among items in a container.
learningObjectives: Understand Flexbox container and item properties
Build navigation bars and card layouts

slides.title: Introduction to Flexbox
slides.content:
Introduction to Flexbox

Flexbox (Flexible Box Layout) is a CSS layout module designed to provide a more efficient way to lay out, align, and distribute space among items in a container, even when their size is unknown or dynamic.

Flexbox makes it easy to create responsive layouts without using floats or positioning.

slides.title: Flex Container Properties
slides.content:
Flex Container Properties

To use Flexbox, set display: flex on the parent element. Key properties include:

  • flex-direction: row, column, row-reverse, column-reverse
  • justify-content: flex-start, center, flex-end, space-between, space-around
  • align-items: stretch, flex-start, center, flex-end, baseline
  • flex-wrap: nowrap, wrap, wrap-reverse

slides.title: Flex Item Properties
slides.content:
Flex Item Properties

Flex items have their own properties that control how they behave:

  • flex-grow: How much the item should grow (default: 0)
  • flex-shrink: How much the item should shrink (default: 1)
  • flex-basis: Initial size of the item
  • flex: Shorthand for grow, shrink, and basis
  • align-self: Override container's align-items for individual items

slides.title: Common Flexbox Patterns
slides.content:
Common Flexbox Patterns

Navigation bar:

.nav { display: flex; justify-content: space-between; }

Card layout:

.cards { display: flex; flex-wrap: wrap; gap: 1rem; }

Centered content:

.center { display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; }

slides.title: Flexbox vs. Other Layouts
slides.content:
Flexbox vs. Other Layouts

Flexbox is ideal for:

  • One-dimensional layouts (row or column)
  • Aligning items within a container
  • Distributing space between items
  • Reordering items visually

For two-dimensional layouts, consider CSS Grid instead.

title: Responsive Web Design
summary: Create websites that work on all devices.
description: Learn how to make your websites responsive using media queries, flexible grids, and responsive images. Your sites will look great on phones, tablets, and desktops.
learningObjectives: Use media queries for different screen sizes
Work with responsive units (rem, em, %, vw, vh)

slides.title: What is Responsive Design?
slides.content:
What is Responsive Design?

Responsive web design makes web pages render well on all devices and window sizes. It uses flexible layouts, flexible images, and CSS media queries to adapt the layout to the viewing environment.

With responsive design, you can create one website that works on desktop, tablet, and mobile devices.

slides.title: Media Queries
slides.content:
Media Queries

Media queries allow you to apply different styles based on device characteristics:

@media (max-width: 768px) {
  .container { padding: 1rem; }
  .sidebar { display: none; }
}

Common breakpoints: 576px (small), 768px (medium), 992px (large), 1200px (extra large).

slides.title: Mobile-First Approach
slides.content:
Mobile-First Approach

Start designing for mobile devices first, then add styles for larger screens:

/* Mobile styles */
.container { width: 100%; }

/* Tablet and up */
@media (min-width: 768px) {
  .container { width: 750px; }
}

/* Desktop and up */
@media (min-width: 992px) {
  .container { width: 970px; }
}

slides.title: Responsive Units
slides.content:
Responsive Units

  • rem/em: Relative to font-size (accessible)
  • %: Relative to parent element
  • vw/vh: Relative to viewport width/height
  • vmin/vmax: Relative to smaller/larger viewport dimension

Use relative units instead of fixed pixels for better responsiveness.

slides.title: Responsive Images
slides.content:
Responsive Images

Use responsive images that scale with the container:

img {
  max-width: 100%;
  height: auto;
}

For different image sizes per device, use the srcset attribute or CSS background images with media queries.

slides.title: Testing Responsive Design
slides.content:
Testing Responsive Design

Test your responsive designs using:

  • Browser developer tools (responsive mode)
  • Real devices when possible
  • Online testing tools
  • Different browsers and orientations

Always test touch interactions on actual mobile devices.

title: JavaScript Fundamentals
summary: Learn the basics of JavaScript programming.
description: JavaScript brings interactivity to web pages. Learn about variables, data types, operators, and basic programming concepts.
learningObjectives: Work with strings, numbers, and booleans

slides.title: What is JavaScript?
slides.content:
What is JavaScript?

JavaScript is a programming language that adds interactivity to web pages. It runs in the browser and allows you to create dynamic content, control multimedia, animate images, and much more.

JavaScript is one of the three core technologies of web development, alongside HTML and CSS.

slides.title: Variables and Data Types
slides.content:
Variables and Data Types

Variables store data values. JavaScript has several data types:

  • Strings: Text data ('Hello World')
  • Numbers: Numeric values (42, 3.14)
  • Booleans: True/false values (true, false)
  • Arrays: Collections of values ([1, 2, 3])
  • Objects: Complex data structures

slides.title: Declaring Variables
slides.content:
Declaring Variables

Use let, const, or var to declare variables:

let name = 'John';        // Can be reassigned
const age = 25;          // Cannot be reassigned
let score;               // Undefined initially
score = 100;             // Assign later

Use const for values that won't change, let for variables that will.

slides.title: Operators
slides.content:
Operators

JavaScript has various operators for calculations and comparisons:

  • Arithmetic: +, -, *, /, %
  • Assignment: =, +=, -=, *=
  • Comparison: ==, ===, !=, <, >
  • Logical: &&, ||, !

slides.title: Basic JavaScript Program
slides.content:
Basic JavaScript Program

Here's a simple program that demonstrates basic concepts:

let name = 'Alice';
let age = 30;
let isStudent = true;

console.log('Hello, ' + name + '!');
console.log('You are ' + age + ' years old.');

if (isStudent) {
  console.log('You are a student.');
} else {
  console.log('You are not a student.');
}

title: JavaScript Functions
description: Functions are reusable blocks of code that perform specific tasks. Learn how to define, call, and use functions effectively in your programs.

slides.title: What are Functions?
slides.content:
What are Functions?

Functions are reusable blocks of code that perform specific tasks. They allow you to write code once and use it multiple times, making your programs more organized and maintainable.

Functions can take input (parameters), process it, and return output (return values).

slides.title: Function Declaration
slides.content:
Function Declaration

The basic syntax for declaring a function:

function functionName(parameter1, parameter2) {
  // Code to execute
  return result;
}

Example:

function greet(name) {
  return 'Hello, ' + name + '!';
}

slides.title: Calling Functions
slides.content:
Calling Functions

To execute a function, you call it by its name followed by parentheses:

let message = greet('Alice');
console.log(message); // Output: Hello, Alice!

greet('Bob'); // Output: Hello, Bob!

You can call functions multiple times with different arguments.

slides.title: Parameters and Arguments
slides.content:
Parameters and Arguments

Parameters are variables defined in the function declaration. Arguments are the values passed when calling the function:

function add(a, b) {  // a and b are parameters
  return a + b;
}

add(5, 3);  // 5 and 3 are arguments

Functions can have zero or more parameters.

slides.title: Return Values
slides.content:
Return Values

The return statement sends a value back to the caller:

function calculateArea(width, height) {
  let area = width * height;
  return area;
}

let roomArea = calculateArea(10, 8);
console.log('Room area:', roomArea); // 80

If no return statement, the function returns undefined.

slides.title: Function Scope
slides.content:
Function Scope

Variables declared inside functions are local to that function:

function myFunction() {
  let localVar = 'I am local';
  console.log(localVar); // Works
}

console.log(localVar); // Error: localVar is not defined

Variables declared outside functions are global and accessible everywhere.

slides.title: Arrow Functions
slides.content:
Arrow Functions

Arrow functions provide a shorter syntax for function expressions:

// Traditional function expression
const add = function(a, b) {
  return a + b;
};

// Arrow function
const add = (a, b) => a + b;

// Arrow function with body
const greet = name => {
  return 'Hello, ' + name;
};

title: DOM Manipulation
summary: Interact with web pages using the DOM.
description: The Document Object Model (DOM) allows JavaScript to interact with HTML elements. Learn how to select, modify, and create elements dynamically.

slides.title: What is the DOM?
slides.content:
What is the DOM?

The Document Object Model (DOM) is a programming interface for HTML and XML documents. It represents the page as a tree of objects that JavaScript can interact with.

The DOM allows JavaScript to change the document structure, style, and content dynamically.

slides.title: Selecting Elements
slides.content:
Selecting Elements

JavaScript provides several methods to select DOM elements:

  • getElementById: document.getElementById('myId')
  • getElementsByClassName: document.getElementsByClassName('myClass')
  • getElementsByTagName: document.getElementsByTagName('p')
  • querySelector: document.querySelector('.myClass')
  • querySelectorAll: document.querySelectorAll('p')

slides.title: Modifying Content
slides.content:
Modifying Content

Change element content using textContent or innerHTML:

let element = document.getElementById('myElement');
element.textContent = 'New text content';
element.innerHTML = 'New HTML content';

Use textContent for plain text, innerHTML for HTML content.

slides.title: Modifying Styles
slides.content:
Modifying Styles

Change element styles using the style property:

let element = document.querySelector('.box');
element.style.backgroundColor = 'blue';
element.style.fontSize = '20px';
element.style.display = 'none';

You can also add/remove CSS classes:

element.classList.add('active');
element.classList.remove('hidden');
element.classList.toggle('visible');

slides.title: Event Handling
slides.content:
Event Handling

Respond to user interactions with event listeners:

let button = document.getElementById('myButton');
button.addEventListener('click', function() {
  alert('Button clicked!');
});

Common events: click, mouseover, keydown, submit, load.

slides.title: Creating Elements
slides.content:
Creating Elements

Create new elements and add them to the DOM:

let newDiv = document.createElement('div');
newDiv.textContent = 'Hello World!';
newDiv.className = 'greeting';

document.body.appendChild(newDiv);

Use appendChild, insertBefore, or insertAdjacentHTML to add elements.

slides.title: DOM Traversal
slides.content:
DOM Traversal

Navigate through the DOM tree:

  • Parent: element.parentElement
  • Children: element.children, element.firstElementChild
  • Siblings: element.nextElementSibling, element.previousElementSibling

These properties help you move around the DOM structure.
